item.title: Best Open-World RPGs for Leading a Faction
item.description:
Faction leadership in open-world RPGs taps into a unique power fantasy, one rooted less in personal conquest and more in influence, diplomacy, and commanding loyalty. Unlike linear experiences, these games give players the freedom to choose allegiances or even build their own kingdoms from nothing with a more strategic form of control that often involves making choices with far-reaching consequences rather than simply defeating the next big boss.

Some games simulate this with systems that prioritize realism, while others deliver it through narrative choices and player reputation. In both cases, they offer rich, emergent gameplay where the world responds to the player's growing authority. Whether it's forming armies, swaying courts, or toppling governments, many RPGs reach a new high in open-world faction control, blending scale and freedom with meaningful responsibility.

Kingdom Come: Deliverance

A Noble Path to Influence

Kingdom Come: Deliverance
10
7.6 /10
Released
February 13, 2018

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

Developer(s)
Warhorse Studios
Publisher(s)
Deep Silver
Platform(s)
PS4, Xbox One, PC, Switch
OpenCritic Rating
Fair
Powered by

Kingdom Come: Deliverance offers a grounded medieval experience in which joining and rising through noble courts actively shapes regional politics. Reputation impacts mercantile prices and faction trust, making political navigation feel meaningful in its historical context in a world that rewards players for leading their cause.

Combat mastery and feudal service grant increasing sway over noble factions. While not overtly about ruling kingdoms, the game realistically captures the ascent through faction ranks, offering a quieter but credible sense of leadership as players become respected figures within a fractured Bohemian realm.

Fallout 4

From Humble Beginnings to Leading the Charge

Fallout 4
9 /10
52
8.8 /10
Released
November 10, 2015

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

Developer(s)
Bethesda
Publisher(s)
Bethesda
Platform(s)
PC, PlayStation 4, PlayStation 5, Xbox One, Xbox Series X, Xbox Series S
OpenCritic Rating
Mighty
Powered by

Fallout 4 introduces a faction system that builds in weight over the course of the entire story. Players can champion the Brotherhood of Steel, Institute, Railroad, or Minutemen, each offering different philosophies and end-game missions to incentivize a strong allegiance to a specific cause.

A custom settlement network also grows under player guidance, becoming a tangible symbol of faction-driven progress across the world, and territorial influence delivers a measurable sense of power and control over the wasteland. Base defense missions and settlement management turn what started as a solo wanderer into a community builder who shapes the Commonwealth’s destiny.

GreedFall

Diplomacy Amid a Colonial Frontier

GreedFall
9.5 /10
Released
September 10, 2019

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

Developer(s)
Spiders
Publisher(s)
Focus Home Interactive
Platform(s)
PS4, Xbox One, PC, PS5, Xbox Series X, Xbox Series S
OpenCritic Rating
Strong
Powered by

GreedFall immerses players in colonial-era politics, where allegiances to various groups can shape the fate of an entire island nation. Each faction has a distinct identity and agenda, influencing trade and the game's multiple endings, as well as the quests that the player can access along the way. This system forces nuanced choices, making the politics feel personal and impactful rather than following a set script.

The game balances combat with dialogue and diplomacy, often requiring negotiation rather than swordplay to navigate the intricate questlines. While Greenfall isn't a true open-world game, featuring semi-open environments instead, it excels in faction-based interactions through managing alliances, seeking or instigating conflict, and in how players drive factional outcomes, cementing its place on this list celebrating faction leadership.

The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt

Deciding the Fate of Vast Regions

The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt
9 /10
53
9.5 /10
Released
May 19, 2015

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL

Developer(s)
CD Projekt Red
Publisher(s)
CD Projekt Red
Platform(s)
Nintendo Switch, PC, PlayStation 4, PlayStation 5, Xbox One, Xbox Series X, Xbox Series S
OpenCritic Rating
Mighty
Powered by

The Witcher 3 places players at the heart of factional warfare between Nilfgaard, Scoia'tael, and the Northern Realms in a regional conflict that stands as far more than a petty quarrel. Geralt’s choices sway allegiances and can determine the victors for many battles, and major quests exemplify how one man’s actions can tip the balance.

Even without a crown, Geralt acts as a power broker. His alliances, the fate of regions like Velen and Novigrad, and the script-altering outcomes of key decisions place him at the nexus of factional influence, delivering the sense that the world pivots on his will.

Cyberpunk 2077

Controlling the Entire Underworld

6 Images
6 Images
Cyberpunk 2077
6 /10
112
8.9 /10
Released
December 10, 2020

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

Developer(s)
CD Projekt Red
Publisher(s)
CD Projekt Red
Platform(s)
PlayStation 5, PlayStation 4, Xbox Series X, Xbox Series S, Xbox One, Nintendo Switch 2, PC
OpenCritic Rating
Strong
Powered by

Cyberpunk 2077 pits players against Night City’s megacorps and gangs, where they can forge alliances and influence street-level power through every choice they make. Lifepath backgrounds also grant initial ties to factions that unlock unique story content and access, giving a sense of embedded influence in an immersive world full of conflict.

In its own unique way, Night City reacts to the player’s loyalties. Support for factions like the Maelstrom or the Aldecaldos biker gang shapes narrative threads and mission lines, and the player's alliances can determine territorial clashes and social standing, making this urban jungle a political sandbox of a different sort.

Mount & Blade 2: Bannerlord

Become a Ruthless Warlord

Mount & Blade 2: Bannerlord
8.0 /10
Released
October 25, 2022

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

Developer(s)
TaleWorlds Entertainment
Publisher(s)
TaleWorlds Entertainment
Platform(s)
PC, PS4, PS5, Xbox One, Xbox Series X, Xbox Series S
OpenCritic Rating
Strong
Powered by

Mount & Blade II: Bannerlord offers plenty of freedom in terms of factional leadership. Players start as mercenaries and rise to found their own clan or lead existing kingdoms, where territory is gained through conquest, politics, and marriages, and factions are dynamic alliances that shift through betrayal and rebellions, diverging based on the players' actions and reputation.

This sandbox epitomizes the rise-to-power fantasy. With no fixed story and full control over armies, diplomacy, economics, and warfare, players become true power brokers in a world where victory feels earned and satisfying every single time.

Fallout: New Vegas

Commanding Battles Between Rivals

Fallout: New Vegas
8 /10
22
8.9 /10
Released
October 19, 2010

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

Developer(s)
Obsidian Entertainment
Publisher(s)
Bethesda
Platform(s)
PS3, Xbox 360, PC
Powered by

Fallout: New Vegas remains the gold standard for open-world faction gameplay. With major groups like NCR, Caesar’s Legion, Mr. House, and Yes Man vying for control, every action shifts the balance of power in one group's favor or the other. The reputation system ensures no faction remains neutral forever, and seeing the world transform through minor to major events is a powerful reward.

Final missions hinge heavily on player choices, and they really have a significant amount of control over how certain events resolve throughout the narrative. The ability to control entire factions as a single individual lends an immense feeling of power and esteem to the player, making them feel truly important in an otherwise fractured world.

The Elder Scrolls 5: Skyrim

Leading Factions Across the Lands

6 Images
6 Images
The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim
9 /10
80
9.5 /10
Released
November 11, 2011

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

Developer(s)
Bethesda Game Studios
Publisher(s)
Bethesda Softworks
Platform(s)
PC, PlayStation 3, PlayStation 4, PlayStation 5, Nintendo Switch, Xbox 360, Xbox One, Xbox Series X, Xbox Series S
OpenCritic Rating
Strong
Powered by

Skyrim may seem like a personal saga, but its faction systems are deep and transformative. Players can join multiple guilds, each with its own HQs, perks, and questlines that are unique to each path. The main civil war forces a definitive factional alignment, with players leading either the imperial or Stormcloak armies to seize control of Skyrim.

Beyond war, players can ascend to leadership roles like Arch-Mage or Guild Master, gaining followers and influence over individuals and the lands themselves. Faction progression reshapes gameplay and changes the world’s structure in meaningful ways, creating the most complete open-world RPG fantasy for players who want to lead, command, and rule.

item.title: Warhammer Age Of Sigmar: Most Expensive Order Miniatures, Ranked
item.description:
Summary

  • Age of Sigmar features impressive, detailed Chaos models that are sought after and expensive.
  • Various faction leaders in Age of Sigmar are ornate and dramatic, making great centerpiece miniatures.
  • The setting includes diverse armies battling through Realmgates, with iconic characters like Lord Kroak.

Of all Games Workshop’s many tabletop settings, Age of Sigmar has produced some of the most creative and dynamic miniatures in the company's history. Warhammer Age of Sigmar is the flagship fantasy setting that replaced Games Workshop's original gaming system, Warhammer Fantasy , and has grown into a vibrant and popular hobby.

The game is set in The Mortal Realms, which are physically separate worlds connected by portals known as Realmgates. Through these gates, the many varied armies in the setting battle for survival, domination, or pleasure. Some of the most ornate and impressive models of this setting are the various faction leaders, or warriors of great renown. While these are some of the most sought-after miniatures in Age of Sigmar , they are also some of the most expensive in the range.

10 Auric Runesmiter On Magmadroth

A Proud Fyreslayer War-Priest

  • Price : £74/$118

Found all across the Mortal Realms, the Fyreslayers are a Duardin race of mercenaries and followers of the fallen god Grimnir. These fierce, tempestuous warriors seek the lost Ur-Gold of their deceased deity and will fight for any army that pays enough gold.

Auric Runesmiter on Magmadroth is the perfect centerpiece for a Fyreslayer army. The large, dragon-like Magmadroth carries a war-priest into battle and is a wonderfully detailed and dramatic model. This would make a great painting project for experienced painters looking for a challenge. Additionally, the set also builds an Auric Runeson or Auric Runefather, which can also be built on foot.

9 Lord Kroak

The Most Ancient And Powerful Of The Slann

  • Price : £85/$137

Hailing from the celestial realm of Azyr, the Seraphon are a race of intelligent reptilians who are dedicated to battling the forces of Chaos. Led by the Slann Starmasters, powerful and ancient toad-like beings, the Seraphon are a hammer against the corrupting darkness.

The most ancient and powerful of all Slann is the relic priest, Lord Kroak , whose deathly, mummified appearance belies his enormous power. Sitting upon an ornate palanquin, this model is a must-have addition for any Seraphon collector. This character is the oldest wizard in the Mortal Realms and the closest link to the ancient Old Ones in the setting.

8 Akhelian Leviadon

A Perfect Centerpiece

  • Price : £87.50/$145

Dwelling deep within the oceans of the Mortal Realms in their hidden Enclaves, the mysterious Idoneth Deepkin are a race of Aelves who are masters of sudden, swift raids. These cursed Aelven people must regularly harvest the souls of mortals to push back the ever-encroaching madness that afflicts their people.

The Akhelian Leviadon is one of the most detailed and dramatic models in the Deepkin range. Featuring a giant turtle-like creature with powerful fins and razor-sharp teeth, the Leviadon is ridden by the Ma’harr, the master of the reins. This is a stunning centerpiece miniature that is just as eye-catching on the tabletop as it is on a display shelf.

7 Eidolon Of Mathlann – Aspect Of The Sea

A Powerful Avatar Of Vengeance

  • Price : £87.50/$145

The elusive Idoneth Deepkin are well-known for their lightning-fast raids and hidden underwater homes. However, they are not entirely safe from attacks by the many forces that roam the Mortal Realms. During the most dire situations, the Idoneth call upon the collective souls of their ancestors, stored in the enclave’s chorrileum, to bring forth an Eidolon of Mathlann . Taking the form of an ancient Aelven god, these beings represent the vengeful power of the ocean.

This beautifully designed model can be built as either the Aspect of the Sea or the Aspect of the Storm, with the Eidolon’s long, water-like cloak drawing the eye. This would make an excellent display model and pose a fun painting challenge for experienced hobbyists.

6 Arkanaut Ironclad

An Impenetrable Floating Fortress

  • Price : £87.50/$145

Few factions in the Age of Sigmar setting are as technologically advanced as the Kharadron Overlords. These Duardin warriors are highly militaristic, relying on their secular scientific advancements to control the skies over the Mortal Realms.

For hobbyists looking to build a Kharadron army, the Arkanaut Ironclad is a must-have addition. As the heaviest of the Kharadron airships, this huge floating fortress provides devastating destructive power, as it rains down armor-piercing torpedoes on unlucky foes. Hugely detailed, with a selection of optional paraphernalia, this miniature makes for a fun project that will look great on the display shelf.

5 Tahlia Vedra, Lioness Of The Parch

The Hero Of The Cities Of Sigmar

  • Price : £95/$158

The first Marshal of the Hammerhal Aqsha, Tahlia Vedra , is a legendary leader and tactical mastermind among the Cities of Sigmar, also known as the Free Cities. Known as the Lioness of the Parch , she rides into battle upon her mount, the manticore Infernadine.

This highly detailed and dramatic model is an eye-catching centerpiece for a Cities of Sigmar army. With the manticore posed in a furious roar, and with Tahlia sitting upon an ornate saddle, this miniature is another great example of Age of Sigmar ’s continued quality. Tahlia can also be armed with various weapon options and adorned with either a full-face helmet or her crown of office.

4 Morathi-Khaine And The Shadow Queen

The Leader Of The Daughters Of Khaine

  • Price : £100/$168

The Daughters of Khaine are an Aelf faction who worship the god of murder and war, Khaine. While their deity was shattered during the End Times of the World-That-Was, these bloodthirsty warriors fight in the hope their god will one day return to power.

This fantastic set depicts the faction leader, Morathi-Khaine , and offers two options for the character. The High Oracle of Khaine is a smaller miniature, with stunning ornate armor. Meanwhile, the horrifying Shadow Queen miniature depicts Morathi in her monstrous true form and is three times larger than its counterpart. This larger miniature evokes the classic monster of legend, Medusa, and is a brilliant centerpiece for the collection.

3 Alarielle The Everqueen

The Goddess Of Life And Nature

  • Price : £100/$168

Alarielle is an ancient and powerful deity of nature and life, and the creator of the Sylvaneth, who has returned to her former might to battle the corrupting forces of Chaos throughout the Mortal Realms.

The Sylvaneth are a race of humanoid tree spirits that have spread from their home in the Realm of Life to the rest of the Mortal Realms. For Age of Sigmar collectors looking to complete their Sylvaneth army, Alarielle the Everqueen is a must-have centerpiece. Riding on her colossal Wardroth Beetle, this model is highly detailed and dynamic, and makes for a challenging and worthwhile painting project.

2 Lord-Celestant On Stardrake

A Heroic Miniature

  • Price : £110/$179

The Stormcast Eternals are the God-King Sigmar’s frontline against the forces of Chaos. Each one is a human soul forged into a near-immortal superhuman warrior. Once defeated, each Eternal is then reforged anew by Sigmar. However, this process is far from perfect, with each individual losing a piece of themselves through the process.

The Lord-Celestants are hand-picked warriors of exceptional skill and character, who are tasked with leading the Stormhost Chambers into battle. This large model depicts a Lord-Celestant atop a winged Stardrake , who leads the most elite Stormhost forces of the Extremis Chamber. This dramatic miniature is highly detailed and a challenge for any painter. It also comes with an additional Drakesworn Templar.

1 Archmage Teclis And Celennar, Spirit Of Hysh

An Icon Of The Age Of Sigmar

  • Price : £115/$194

During the end times of the World-That-Was, the Chaos god Slaanesh consumed the souls of the Aelven races. While many of these were recovered and reshaped by the deities of the Aelves, the purest of these are the Lumineth Realm-Lords, whose magic, power, and advanced culture are focused on ending the threat of Chaos in the Mortal Realms.

This stunning model depicts Teclis , the leader of the Lumineth Realm-Lords and one of the surviving deities from the World-That-Was. This stunning model is one of the most original and iconic in the Age of Sigmar range and depicts the Archmage together with the lunasphinx, Celennar . This miniature is great for an advanced painting project, and it is the ultimate collector's piece for fans of the fantasy setting.

item.title: Marvel Rivals Reveals Controversial Matchmaking Change
item.description:
Marvel Rivals players are unhappy with the upcoming matchmaking limitations revealed by NetEase. The adjustment will be available with the launch of Marvel Rivals Season 3.5, which will bring new features and changes to shake up the shooter and keep the experience engaging.

Marvel Rivals Season 3 arrived on July 11 with the threat of Knull, the god of symbiotes, as its theme. To combat such a high-level danger, the developers finally added Jean Grey/Phoenix, bringing another playable Duelist to the game. Continuing the tradition of previous seasons, Marvel Rivals has added a new map, Klyntar: Celestial Husk, available in Domination mode. Team-Ups have been modified again, with a new joint ability for Phoenix and Wolverine, and two for the Human Torch – one with Spider-Man and one with The Thing. Marvel Rivals will soon enter the second half of Season 3, but one of the announced features is not making the community very excited.

The Marvel Rivals community reacted negatively to upcoming matchmaking limitations in ranked play, preventing players at Platinum and above from playing in five-person squads. On the game's subreddit, user smaughh called the adjustment "odd," and disagreed that this is the right way to prevent people from playing against “massive stacks." Many of the more than 900 comments expressed sadness, as they play Marvel Rivals with friends in full teams, and the change will make this more difficult. Others argued that this could increase the number of smurf accounts, allowing Marvel Rivals players to play ranked in squads.

Ranked Matchmaking Limitations Receive Backlash From Marvel Rivals Players

With the start of Season 3.5, only Marvel Rivals players in Bronze, Silver, and Gold will be able to play ranked in teams of five. Players who reach Platinum, Diamond, and Grandmaster will only be able to queue with up to three people. For players in the highest ranks of Marvel Rivals – Celestial, Eternity, and One Above All – the limitations will be even more severe, with only up to two players allowed in a team.

Marvel Rivals Season 3.5 arrives on August 8, and in addition to matchmaking adjustments, the patch will finally add Blade to NetEase's shooter. Marvel Rivals Team-Ups will be adjusted, including Blade in the Team-Up with Moon Knight and Cloak and Dagger, and bringing a new joint ability for Adam Warlock and Luna Snow. For fans looking forward to new skins, one of the highlights is the upcoming free costume for The Thing, giving the hero a symbiote makeover.

10 Images
10 Images

item.title: How to Trade in Grow a Garden
item.description:
Trading plays a big role in Grow a Garden , giving players a way to share pets and resources. But for the longest time, the only option was the gifting system, which wasn’t exactly safe, as it left room for scams.

Now, with the 1.17.0 Trading & Cooking update, a proper trading system is finally here. Players can securely lock in trades and swap items without the risk. Here’s how trading works in Grow a Garden .

How to Use Trading Tickets in Grow a Garden

While gifting is still available in the game, trading is definitely the more reliable option. You can safely trade items using Trading Tickets in Grow a Garden ; just head over to the Gear Shop and buy one for 100,000 Sheckles . If you’re not sure where that is, it’s right next to the Cosmetics and Crafting Stand. You can also use a Recall Wrench to teleport there quickly.

To share pets and other stuff (more on that below), you only need one Trading Ticket. Even if the other player doesn’t have one, you can still start the trade.

Just equip the ticket in your character’s hand and press the E button while facing the player’s avatar you want to give things to. Once they accept, a trade window will pop up for both of you.

Then, click the plus button to start adding your Pets and Fruits . For Sheckles, type the amount in the orange “Add Sheckles” button . Each item will show up in your offer section one by one. Your trading partner will do the same. At the top of the trading screen, the system will show the total trade value, so both sides can see if it’s a fair deal. Once you’re both done, hit the “Accept” button, then confirm the trade . After that, you’ll both get the items.

What Can You Trade in Grow a Garden?

At the moment, crop seeds can’t be traded in Grow a Garden , though that might change in a future update. For now, you can only trade the following items:

  • Fruits
  • Pets
  • Sheckles

Each trade lets both players exchange up to 12 items using just one Trading Ticket . These can be all pets or fruits; Sheckles are added separately to their own bar, so they don’t count toward the item limit, which is a nice bonus. However, if the other player’s pet or fruit inventory is full, you won’t be able to add your offer. They’ll need to sell something or clear up space first.

item.title: The Trickster's Shrine Quest Guide in Titan Quest 2
item.description:
There are lots of quest items scattered throughout the world of Titan Quest 2 , and figuring out what they are used for can finish mini-quests that still reward you like it's a side quest. You're usually given little to no direction on how to use these quest items, but knowing where to go can make these great ways to level up fast and get new gear.

It's also not uncommon to find the use for a quest item before finding the quest item itself, and either can be true in the case of the Caduceus. This large staff is used to begin the Trickster's Shrine quest, which involves a riddle about Hermes and killing a specific monster in a specific way, though this has no connection to the Strange Jar and his problem with Hermes.

Where to Find the Caduceus & How to Use it in Titan Quest 2

The Caduceus is found in a small bandit camp, with only a few enemies within, northeast of Pyrgos in the Southern Flooded Farmland area . You can either choose to go through the marsh to get straight there or loop your way north, following the general direction of "The Search For the Sky God" quest before heading straight east.

Once you have the Caduceus, take it to the Shrieking Shrine , also northwest of Pyrgos but more north than the Caduceus was found. Place the staff into the pedestal in the center of the Shrine to start the quest, "The Trickster Shrine."

What Beast Did Hermes Turn into a Lyre in Titan Quest 2

This quest is fairly short but requires you to know which beast Hermes slayed first. The answer is on a mostly destroyed scroll found near the pots to the right of the pedestal, a turtle . Head out of the Shrieking Shrine to the south to find a turtle out front, but don't kill it.

If you've already killed all the nearby turtle enemies, you can simply reload your game back to the main menu to respawn them.

Once you find a turtle, you'll need to lure it back to the Shrine without killing it before getting there . The turtle won't do much damage, no matter your attributes, and as long as you stay right in front of them and don't run ahead, it will follow you the whole way. Once the turtle gets close enough to the shrine, it will begin to glow, indicating you're safe to kill the turtle. Doing so will finish the quest and give various amounts of gold thrown out of the center altar that can be picked up.
